bestBHT.bht: Around six in the evening, Jesus alluded to the future consummation of the kingdom, signifying the abrogation of the old Passover rite and the introduction of the new one. He mentioned not partaking in the Supper He later instituted, emphasizing the significance of the kingdom of God. Through the statement of not drinking the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes, Jesus portrayed the pouring forth of the Spirit, conversions, Jewish destruction, and the ultimate state of happiness and bliss in the world to come.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Between three and this hour the lamb was killed ( :-, Margin)
Philip Schaff: From this we infer that our Lord did not partake in the Supper He afterwards instituted.
The verse points to the same event in the future as Luke 22:16.
The old rite was thus formally abrogated, the new one about to be instituted.
Archibald T. Robertson: The fruit of the vine... allows anything that is 'the fruit of the vine.'
Here it is the consummation of the kingdom that Jesus has in mind.
For the kingdom had already come.
John Gill: For I say unto you, I will not drink of the fruit of the vine... until the kingdom of God shall come."
The pouring forth of the Spirit on the apostles... in the conversion of great multitudes... in the destruction of the Jews... in the latter day glory;
The ultimate state of happiness and bliss in the world to come.

bhtAttempts.bht: At about six in the evening, Jesus mentioned the future consummation of the kingdom, indicating that the old Passover rite was about to be abrogated and the new one instituted. By saying that he will not drink of the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes, Jesus alludes to the pouring forth of the Spirit, the conversion of many, the destruction of the Jews, and the ultimate state of happiness and bliss in the world to come. This verse thus highlights the significance of the kingdom of God and the transformative power it holds.

Around six in the evening, Jesus alluded to the future consummation of the kingdom, signifying the abrogation of the old Passover rite and the introduction of the new one. He mentioned not partaking in the Supper He later instituted, emphasizing the significance of the kingdom of God. Through the statement of not drinking the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes, Jesus portrayed the pouring forth of the Spirit, conversions, Jewish destruction, and the ultimate state of happiness and bliss in the world to come.

At about six in the evening, Jesus spoke about the future consummation of the kingdom, suggesting the abolishment of the old Passover rite and the establishment of the new one. He emphasized the significance of the kingdom of God by stating that he will not drink of the fruit of the vine until it comes. This implies the outpouring of the Spirit, numerous conversions, the destruction of the Jews, and the eventual state of everlasting happiness in the world to come.

Around six in the evening, Jesus alluded to the future consummation of the kingdom, signifying the abrogation of the old Passover rite and the introduction of the new one. By saying he will not drink of the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes, Jesus highlighted the pouring forth of the Spirit, conversions, Jewish destruction, and the eventual state of everlasting happiness in the world to come. This emphasizes the significance of the kingdom of God and its transformative power.

Around six in the evening, Jesus spoke of the future consummation of the kingdom, indicating the abrogation of the old Passover rite and the establishment of the new one. He emphasized the significance of the kingdom of God, stating that he will not drink of the fruit of the vine until it comes. This points towards the pouring forth of the Spirit, conversions, the destruction of the Jews, and the eventual state of everlasting happiness in the world to come.
